title: Boolean Logic: The Language of Yes and No
concept:
Imagine you're at a door with an electronic lock. The lock doesn't care about your story, your excuses, or your good intentions. It asks one simple question:

"Is the code correct?"

The answer can only be:

  • YES → The door unlocks
  • NO → The door stays locked

There's no "maybe," no "almost," no "it depends." Just YES or NO. TRUE or FALSE.

This is Boolean logic - named after mathematician George Boole, who realized that all logical reasoning boils down to true/false questions.

Real-World Examples of Boolean Thinking:

  • Traffic light: "Is the light green?" → True = Go, False = Stop
  • Email login: "Is the password correct?" → True = Log in, False = Show error
  • Shopping cart: "Is the total over $50?" → True = Free shipping, False = Pay shipping
  • Age verification: "Is age >= 18?" → True = Allow, False = Deny

Every decision a computer makes starts with these yes/no questions. In Python, we call these questions Boolean expressions, and the answers are Boolean values: True or False.

The Foundation of All Programming Decisions:

Remember the calculator from Module 2? When we checked if choice == 1:, we were asking a Boolean question:

"Is the user's choice equal to 1?"

The answer (True or False) determined which path the program took. Now you'll learn how to ask these questions deliberately and powerfully!

code_example.code:
# Boolean Values: True and False
# These are actual values in Python, just like numbers or strings

is_raining = True
is_sunny = False

print("Is it raining?", is_raining)  # Output: True
print("Is it sunny?", is_sunny)       # Output: False
print("Data type:", type(is_raining)) # Output: <class 'bool'>

print()

# Comparison Operators: Asking Questions
# These operators RETURN boolean values (True or False)

age = 25
min_age = 18

# Equal to (==)
print("Is age exactly 25?", age == 25)      # True
print("Is age exactly 30?", age == 30)      # False

# Not equal to (!=)
print("Is age NOT 30?", age != 30)           # True

# Greater than (>)
print("Is age greater than min_age?", age > min_age)  # True (25 > 18)

# Less than (<)
print("Is age less than min_age?", age < min_age)     # False (25 is not < 18)

# Greater than or equal (>=)
print("Is age >= min_age?", age >= min_age)  # True (25 >= 18)

# Less than or equal (<=)
print("Is age <= 30?", age <= 30)            # True (25 <= 30)

print()

# Booleans in Action: Making Decisions
price = 45
free_shipping_threshold = 50

qualifies_for_free_shipping = price >= free_shipping_threshold
print(f"Price: ${price}")
print(f"Qualifies for free shipping?", qualifies_for_free_shipping)
# Output: False (because 45 < 50)

syntax_breakdown:
Understanding Boolean Values:

1. True and False - The Only Boolean Values

is_valid = True   # Capitalized!
is_error = False  # Capitalized!

Critical: Boolean values MUST be capitalized in Python:

  • ✅ True - Correct
  • ❌ true - Error! Python won't recognize it
  • ✅ False - Correct
  • ❌ false - Error! Python won't recognize it

Python is case-sensitive, so capitalization matters!

2. The Six Comparison Operators

These operators ask questions and return True or False:

OperatorMeaningExampleResult
==Equal to5 == 5True
!=Not equal to5 != 3True
>Greater than10 > 5True
<Less than3 < 10True
>=Greater than or equal5 >= 5True
<=Less than or equal3 <= 5True

3. Common Beginner Confusion: == vs =

# WRONG: Using = (assignment) when you mean == (comparison)
age = 18      # Assignment: "Make age equal to 18"
if age = 18:  # ERROR! This is trying to assign, not compare

# CORRECT: Using == (comparison)
age = 18      # Assignment: "Make age equal to 18"
if age == 18: # Comparison: "Is age equal to 18?" (Returns True/False)

Memory trick:

  • = (one equal sign) → Make it equal (assignment)
  • == (two equal signs) → Check if equal (comparison)

4. Storing Boolean Results in Variables

You can store the result of a comparison in a variable:

is_adult = age >= 18          # Stores True or False
has_permission = score > 80   # Stores True or False
is_valid_username = len(name) >= 3  # Stores True or False

This makes your code more readable!

5. Comparing Strings

Comparison operators work with strings too:

name = "Alice"

print(name == "Alice")   # True (exact match, case-sensitive!)
print(name == "alice")   # False (different case)
print(name != "Bob")     # True (not equal)

# Alphabetical comparison
print("apple" < "banana")  # True ('a' comes before 'b')
print("Zoo" < "apple")     # True (capital letters come before lowercase!)

Important: String comparison is case-sensitive! "Hello" != "hello"

6. Truthy and Falsy Values (Advanced Preview)

In Python, almost any value can be treated as True or False in a Boolean context:

# Falsy values (treated as False):
0              # Zero is False
0.0            # Zero float is False
""             # Empty string is False
None           # None is False

# Truthy values (treated as True):
1, -5, 100     # Any non-zero number is True
"hello", "0"   # Any non-empty string is True (even "0"!)

Note: You'll use this more in later modules. For now, focus on True, False, and comparison operators.

exercise.instructions:
Build a Movie Ticket Validator that checks if someone can watch different movie ratings.

Your task:

  1. Ask the user for their age
  2. Create Boolean variables that check if they can watch movies rated:
    • G (General - any age)
    • PG-13 (13 and older)
    • R (17 and older)
  3. Display which ratings they can watch

Example output:

Enter your age: 15

Movie Rating Access:
• G-rated movies: True
• PG-13 movies: True
• R-rated movies: False

You can watch 2 out of 3 rating categories!

Hints:

  • Use >= to check if age meets the minimum
  • G-rated has no minimum (everyone can watch)
  • Count how many ratings are True

# Get user's age

print("\nMovie Rating Access:")

can_watch_g = True  # G-rated: Everyone can watch

can_watch_pg13 =   # PG-13: Age 13 and older

can_watch_r =      # R-rated: Age 17 and older

# Display results
print(f"• G-rated movies: {can_watch_g}")
print(f"• PG-13 movies: {can_watch_pg13}")
print(f"• R-rated movies: {can_watch_r}")

# Bonus: Count how many True values

exercise.hint: Use the >= operator to check if the age meets the minimum. For example: can_watch_pg13 = age >= 13 will return True if age is 13 or higher, False otherwise. For can_watch_g, since everyone can watch G-rated movies, it's always True!

solution.code:
# Movie Ticket Validator - SOLUTION
# Check which movie ratings someone can watch

# Get user's age
age = int(input("Enter your age: "))

print("\nMovie Rating Access:")

# Create Boolean variables for each rating
can_watch_g = True  # G-rated: Everyone can watch

can_watch_pg13 = age >= 13  # PG-13: Age 13 and older

can_watch_r = age >= 17  # R-rated: Age 17 and older

# Display results
print(f"• G-rated movies: {can_watch_g}")
print(f"• PG-13 movies: {can_watch_pg13}")
print(f"• R-rated movies: {can_watch_r}")

# Bonus: Count how many True values
# (Because True == 1 and False == 0, we can add them!)
total_accessible = can_watch_g + can_watch_pg13 + can_watch_r
print(f"\nYou can watch {total_accessible} out of 3 rating categories!")
solution.explanation:
How the Solution Works:

  1. Getting the Age:
    age = int(input("Enter your age: "))

    Convert input to an integer since ages are whole numbers.

  2. Boolean Comparisons:
    can_watch_g = True          # Always True (no age restriction)
can_watch_pg13 = age >= 13  # True if 13+, False if younger
can_watch_r = age >= 17     # True if 17+, False if younger

    The >= operator returns True or False, which we store in variables.

  3. Example Walkthrough (age = 15):
    • can_watch_g = True (everyone can watch)
    • can_watch_pg13 = 15 >= 13 → True (15 is >= 13)
    • can_watch_r = 15 >= 17 → False (15 is not >= 17)
  4. The Counting Trick:
    total_accessible = can_watch_g + can_watch_pg13 + can_watch_r
# With age 15: True + True + False = 1 + 1 + 0 = 2

    In Python, True equals 1 and False equals 0, so you can add them to count!

Testing the Program:

AgeGPG-13RTotal
10TrueFalseFalse1
15TrueTrueFalse2
20TrueTrueTrue3

Common Mistakes:

  1. Using = instead of >=:
    # WRONG:
can_watch_r = age = 17  # This tries to assign 17 to age!

# CORRECT:
can_watch_r = age >= 17  # This compares age to 17
  2. Forgetting the second equals sign:
    # WRONG:
can_watch_r = age > = 17  # Space breaks it!

# CORRECT:
can_watch_r = age >= 17   # No space in the operator
  3. Using quotes around True/False:
    # WRONG:
can_watch_g = "True"  # This is a STRING, not a Boolean!

# CORRECT:
can_watch_g = True    # This is the actual Boolean value

Why This Pattern is Powerful:

Storing Boolean results in descriptive variables makes code incredibly readable:

# Instead of this:
if age >= 18 and has_id == True and balance >= 10:

# You can write this:
is_adult = age >= 18
has_valid_id = has_id == True
has_enough_money = balance >= 10

if is_adult and has_valid_id and has_enough_money:
    # Much clearer what we're checking!

This self-documenting code style is a professional best practice!

key_takeaways:
• Boolean values are True or False (capitalized!) - the foundation of all program decisions
  • Comparison operators ask questions and return Boolean values:
    • == equal, != not equal
    • > greater, < less
    • >= greater or equal, <= less or equal
  • Don't confuse:
    • = (assignment: "make it equal")
    • == (comparison: "check if equal")
  • Store Boolean results in variables with descriptive names for readable code
  • String comparisons are case-sensitive: "Hello" ≠ "hello"
  • The data type is called bool (check with type())
  • Mathematical truth: True == 1 and False == 0 (useful for counting!)

Before Moving On:

Make sure you can:

  • Write comparisons using all six operators
  • Explain the difference between = and ==
  • Store Boolean results in variables
  • Predict what a comparison will return (True or False)

Coming Up Next:

In Lesson 2: Logical Operators, you'll learn how to combine multiple Boolean questions:

  • and - "Is this true AND that true?"
  • or - "Is this true OR that true?"
  • not - "Is this NOT true?"

This lets you ask complex questions like: "Is the user an adult AND has a valid ID?" or "Is it the weekend OR a holiday?"
